headline: Pasta ’Ncasciata (Sicilian Baked Pasta)
description: Michael Gulotta’s Pasta ’Ncasciata (Sicilian Baked Pasta) recipe is a hearty pasta with tender eggplant, melty caciocavallo cheese, and crushed tomato sauce.
name: Pasta ’Ncasciata (Sicilian Baked Pasta)
recipeIngredient: 2 small eggplants (about 1 1/2 pounds), unpeeled, stemmed, and sliced crosswise into 1/4-inch-thick rounds
2 (28-ounces) cans whole peeled San Marzano tomatoes, crushed by hand and juices reserved
1 cup fresh or frozen sweet peas (optional)
12 large basil leaves, thinly sliced (about 1/3 cup), plus more for garnish
8 ounces caciocavallo or provolone cheese, grated (about 2 cups)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 425°F. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil over high. Add pasta, and cook according to package instructions for al dente. Drain well, and spread pasta in an even layer on a rimmed baking sheet. Set aside until ready to use.
While pasta cooks, arrange eggplant rounds evenly on a paper towel–lined baking sheet; sprinkle 2 teaspoons salt over both sides of eggplant rounds. Let stand 10 minutes. Pat dry with paper towels.

Brush 2 tablespoons oil evenly on 2 baking sheets. Arrange eggplant rounds in a single layer on baking sheets, and brush 2 tablespoons oil evenly over eggplant rounds. Roast in preheated oven until softened and starting to brown, about 20 minutes. Remove from oven, and set aside until ready to use. Reduce oven temperature to 350°F.

While eggplant roasts, heat remaining 2 tablespoons oil in a large saucepan over medium-high. Add pork and 1/2 teaspoon salt; cook, stirring to break up meat into small pieces, until pork is browned, about 8 minutes. Add onion and garlic; cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 4 minutes. Stir in crushed tomatoes and juices, tomato paste, sugar, and remaining 3 teaspoons salt; bring to a simmer over medium-high. Reduce heat to medium-low to maintain a simmer. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until tomatoes have broken down completely into sauce, about 20 minutes. Remove from heat. Fold in cooked pasta, peas (if using), and sliced basil.

Spread half of the pasta mixture (about 6 cups) in bottom of a 13- x 9-inch baking dish. Top with half of the eggplant and 1 cup caciocavallo. Repeat layers once with remaining pasta mixture, remaining eggplant, and remaining caciocavallo. Sprinkle evenly with Parmigiano-Reggiano.

Cover baking dish with parchment paper, and wrap tightly with aluminum foil. Bake at 350°F until filling is bubbly around the edges and in center (you will need to unwrap the baking dish to check), about 30 minutes. Remove foil and parchment paper, and bake until cheese is golden and bubbly, 10 to 12 minutes. Remove from oven. Garnish with additional basil, and serve.

review.reviewBody: It is time-consuming but easy and totally worth it. I used whole wheat rigatoni and an entire bag of frozen peas to satisfy my preferences, but this is a keeper for sure!
Excellent dish! Served with salad and warm bread.
Awesome recipe . Will try it again..

I loved this dish's warmth, ease of preparation, and full-flavored taste. The second time I made this dish, I used homemade fresh pasta--cooked it less, cuz of the fresh pasta-- added fresh oregano and fennel seeds, along with a salad and baguette. So satisfying!

This is the perfect anecdote to a cold January afternoon. The aroma of eggplant roasting in the oven and freshly made tomato sauce simmering on the stovetop warms the kitchen and hints at the savory goodness to come. I substituted ground turkey for pork and used provolone. I also addd a bit of oregano. The eggplant adds a lovely char flavor to the casserole. Great dish for company!
